title: Verbs Group B (-ao)
reading_greek:
THE PATTERN (Ending is Stressed)
- Μιλάω (I speak)
- Μιλάς (You speak)
- Μιλάει (He/She speaks)
- Μιλάμε (We speak)
- Μιλάτε (You speak)
- Μιλάνε (They speak)

COMMON VERBS
- Αγαπάω -> Αγαπάνε (I love -> They love)
- Πεινάω -> Πεινάω (I am hungry)
- Διψάω -> Διψάω (I am thirsty)
- Περπατάω -> Περπατάς (I walk -> You walk)
- Ρωτάω (I ask)
- Τραγουδάω (I sing)
reading_english:
GRAMMAR: GROUP B VERBS [(See Page 57)](/assets/grammar.pdf#page=57)

1. IDENTIFY IT: The accent is on the ENDING.
   - mi-LA-o.

2. THE 'A' SOUND: These verbs love the letter Alpha. 
   - mil-A-s, mil-A-ei, mil-A-me.

3. CONTRACTED FORM: Sometimes 'Milao' becomes 'Milo'.
   - Same verb, just shorter. Beginners stay with 'Milao'.
audio_script:
Group B Verbs. The loud ones. 

The stress hits the end: 'Mi-LAO'. 'Aga-PAO'.

Notice the 'AAA' sound throughout? 
- MilAs
- MilAei
- MilAme
- MilAte

Common mistake: Confusing Group A and B. 
'Kano' (Group A) -> 'Kano, Kaneis'.
'Agapao' (Group B) -> 'Agapao, Agapas'. 

'Agapas' (You love). Not 'Agapeis'.
